Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the 2.6 percent growth in the nation's real gross domestic product for the second quarter of 2017 by stating that "nobody thought they'd see" such a number for a long period of time, when in fact, higher growth rates have been achieved in previous quarters.
Understate: The claim understates the actual growth rates achieved in previous quarters by implying that the 2.6 percent growth is unprecedented, when in fact, real GDP growth was higher than 2.6 percent in eight of the last 18 quarters.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the assertion that "nobody thought they'd see" a growth rate of 2.6 percent for a long period of time.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the 2.6 percent growth rate is unexpected and unprecedented, when in fact, there were economic models and forecasts that predicted higher growth rates for the second quarter.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation exists for the claim, as the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta initially forecasted a GDP growth rate of 4.3 percent for the second quarter, indicating that the 2.6 percent growth rate was lower than expected.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that real GDP growth was higher than 2.6 percent in eight of the last 18 quarters, as stated by data from the Bureau of Economic Analysis.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not acknowledging the existence of higher growth rates achieved in previous quarters and not providing sufficient context or evidence to support the assertion made.
